message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment is typically erythromycin or tetracycline, and the most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin is methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ointment most commonly used for newborn prophylaxis contains erythromycin, which targets bacterial ribosomes by binding to 23S rRNA in the 50S subunit. Methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site is one of the most common mechanisms of resistance to erythromycin. The other options are not related to resistance to erythromycin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment applied to the newborn is most likely erythromycin or tetracycline, which inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S rRNA. Methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site is a common mechanism of resistance to these antibiotics. The other answer choices are mechanisms of resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics (penicillinase), cell wall synthesis inhibitors (amino acid alteration), and DNA synthesis inhibitors (mutation in DNA polymerase).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment applied to the newborn is likely erythromycin ointment, which works by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibiting protein synthesis. The most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin is methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site, which prevents the drug from binding to the ribosome. Option A refers to resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin. Option B refers to resistance to antibiotics that target the bacterial cell wall, such as cephalosporins or vancomycin. Option C refers to resistance to antibiotics that interfere with DNA replication, such as fluoroquinolones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment most commonly used for prophylaxis against infection in newborns contains erythromycin, which binds to the 23S rRNA-binding site on the bacterial ribosome. The most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin is methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site, which prevents the drug from binding and inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. Option A is incorrect as it refers to resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin, which are not contained in the ophthalmic ointment. Option B is incorrect as it refers to resistance to antibiotics such as vancomycin, which are not contained in the ophthalmic ointment. Option C is incorrect as it refers to resistance to nucleoside analogues such as acyclovir, which are not contained in the ophthalmic ointment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment likely contains erythromycin, which targets the 50S ribosomal subunit. Methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site is the most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin. Option A refers to resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin, option B refers to resistance to vancomycin, and option C refers to resistance to fluoroquinolones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ointment that is commonly applied to newborns is erythromycin ophthalmic ointment, which works by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome and inhibiting protein synthesis. The most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin is methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site, which reduces the binding affinity of the drug to the ribosome. Penicillinase in bacteria cleaves the beta-lactam ring of penicillin, altering amino acid cell wall would affect antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis, and a mutation in DNA polymerase would affect antibiotics that target DNA replication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment applied to the newborn likely contains erythromycin, which targets bacterial ribosomes and prevents protein synthesis. The most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin is methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site, which reduces the drug’s affinity for the ribosome. Option B is incorrect because amino acids do not compose the bacterial cell wall, and option C is incorrect because erythromycin does not target DNA polymerase. Option A is incorrect because penicillinase specifically cleaves beta-lactam antibiotics, not erythromycin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment commonly used for prophylaxis contains erythromycin, which acts by binding to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes and inhibiting protein synthesis. The most common mechanism of resistance to erythromycin is the methylation of 23S rRNA-binding site, which prevents effective binding of erythromycin to the ribosome. Option (A) refers to resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, (B) refers to resistance to cell wall synthesis inhibitors like penicillin, and (C) refers to resistance to nucleic acid synthesis inhibitors like rifampin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic ointment applied to the newborn is usually erythromycin or tetracycline, and resistance to these antibiotics usually occurs through methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site. This interferes with the binding of the antibiotic to the ribosome and decreases its effectiveness. Penicillinase cleaves the beta-lactam ring in penicillin, alteration of amino acid cell wall occurs in bacterial resistance to glycopeptide antibiotics, and mutation in DNA polymerase occurs in resistance to nucleoside analogues.
